7.04(C)
   149.01 ADMINISTRATION.
   (a)    The Municipal Civil Service Commission of the City shall be composed
of three (3) persons who shall be appointed and serve in the manner provided
for in Section
7.04 of the City Charter.
   (b)    The Commission shall administer and enforce the Civil Service laws of
the State, the rules and regulations relative to the Civil Service Commission
of the City and the ordinances of the City.
   (c)    The Commission shall elect, at the first regularly scheduled meeting
of each year, one of its members as Chairman, one as Vice-Chairman and one as
Secretary, to serve for a one year period.
   (d)    It shall be the duty of the Chairman to call such meetings of the
Commission as are necessary to transact the business and affairs of the
Commission, to preside at all meetings of the Commission, to sign the minutes
of all actions taken by the Commission, and sign all warrants or orders for the
payment of money from the accounts and funds of the Commission. The Chairman
may on their own initiative, and shall, upon request of the other two (2)
members of the Commission, call a special meeting of the Commission to be held
not later than ten (10) days from the date of notice of such meeting. In the
absence of the Chairman, the Vice-Chairman shall act as Chairman. Two (2)
members of the Commission shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the
Commission and it shall require the affirmative vote of at least two (2)
members to adopt any motion or resolution.
   (e)    The Secretary shall keep the minutes of all the meetings of the
Commission; shall keep in the form of minutes a record of the official actions
of the Commission; shall be at the office of the Commission during the
prescribed hours that such office is open; shall accurately and properly keep
all the records of the Commission; shall keep all files in proper order; shall
prepare and deliver or cause to be delivered, notices and other communications
ordered by the Commission; shall properly furnish appointing authorities with
eligible lists; shall maintain an official roster; shall handle such
correspondences as the Commission shall determine; shall, in conjunction with
the Chairman, sign all warrants or orders for the payment of money on behalf of
the Commission; and shall perform such other duties as may be required by the
Commission.
 
   (f)    The Commission may elect to employ a suitable person to act as a
clerical secretary for the Commission. (Ord. 2024-78. Passed 10-7-24.)
   149.02 DEFINITIONS.
   The terms herein specified whenever used in the Rules and Regulations of the
Municipal Civil Service Commission or in this chapter shall be construed as
follows:
   (a)    "Commission" means the Municipal Civil Service Commission of the City
of Tiffin, Ohio.
   (b)    "Civil Service" means and includes all officers and positions of
trust or employment in the service of the City of Tiffin, Ohio, and the Tiffin
City School District.
   (c)    "Unclassified service" includes those positions set forth in
subsection (C)(2) of Section
7.04 of the City Charter.
   (d)    "Classified service" includes those positions designated by Section
7.04 (C)(1) of the City Charter.
   (e)    "Municipal service" means those positions in the classified service
of the City.
   (f)    "School service" means those positions in the classified service of
the City School District.
   (g)    "Position" when used by itself means any specific office, employment
or job calling for the performance of certain duties, either full-time or part-
time and for the exercise of certain responsibilities by one individual.
   (h)    "Appointing authority" means the officer having the power of
appointment or removal from positions in the classified service.
   (i)    "Employee" means any person holding a position subject to
appointment, removal, promotion or reduction by an appointing officer.
   (j)    "Score" means that percent of correct answers on a written and/or
assessment examination.
   (k)    "Grade" when used in reference to testing means the score plus any
applicable credits.
   (l)    "Provisional employee" means an employee filling a vacancy m the
classified service who has not been certified.
      (Ord. 2024-78. Passed 10-7-24.)
   149.03 GENERAL EXAMINATIONS.
   (a)    The Commission shall adopt rules and procedures concerning
examinations in accordance with the general laws of Ohio and this chapter.
   (b)    Passing Score. Passing score on all written examinations shall be
seventy percent (70%) of the possible correct answers.
   (c)    Method of Scoring Written Examinations. The total number of questions
shall be divided into 100 to determine the value of each question. This value
multiplied by the number of correct answers shall determine the attained score.
For example: If the examination consisted of 120 questions, that number must be
divided into 100, i.e. 100: 120 questions = .833 value. This value multiplied
by the number of correctly answered questions would give the attained score.
   (d)    Age, Physical or Other Requirements. Any restriction for appointment
from an eligible list as to age, physical or other requirements shall be made
prior to and stated in the bulletin announcing the examination and no eligible
list shall be so restricted unless it had been announced in the examination
bulletin.
(Ord. 2024-78. Passed 10-7-24.)
   149.031 ENTRANCE ELIGIBILITY LIST; ENTRANCE EXAMINATION.
   (a)    Applications for entry level positions within the City of Tiffin
Police Department and Fire/Rescue Division are accepted at any time and remain
valid for twelve (12) months from the date the application is received by the
City. Notice of entrance level eligibility list establishment, including the
application process and deadline shall be given through multiple media sources
including, but not limited to, the local newspapers, social media, email,
radio, and any other medium useful for the delivery of information to the
public. Notices shall appear not more than sixty (60) days or less than
fourteen (14) days prior to the application period.
   (b)    All applicants shall be citizens of the United States.
   (c)    Entrance Examination.
      (1)    Entrance examinations shall be administered via the National
Testing Network. Candidates will be required to attain a weighted score of
seventy percent (70%) to be considered as having a passing score.
   
   (d)    Credit for Military Service.
      (1)    When proof of an honorable discharge from the armed forces of the
United States, or transfer to the reserve with evidence of satisfactory service
is presented to the Commission and such ex-service man or woman being otherwise
eligible has received a passing score of seventy percent (70%) or more in any
regular entrance examination they shall be granted additional credit of twenty
percent (20%) of such score which shall be added to that score to determine the
final grade.
      (2)    Military credit shall apply only to entrance level applicants,
except as provided in Section
149.032(f)(5).
      (3)    Requests for the additional credit for military service, together
with an honorable discharge or other proof of satisfactory service, shall be
submitted to the Commission with application for the examination. Credit for
military service shall not be given if the request for such credit is received
by the Commission after an eligible list for any examination has been
established.
   (e)    Police Department Applicants.
      (1)    Applicants for examination for original appointment to the Police
Department as a police officer shall satisfy the age limits for original
appointment as set forth in Section
141.02 of Tiffin Codified Ordinances on or prior to the date of appointment.
Applicants shall possess a high school
diploma or GED and will present proof of such prior to testing. Applicants must
have current Ohio Peace Officers Training Certificate to take the entry
examination and will present proof of such prior to testing. Any candidate that
is currently in an approved Ohio Police Officer Training Academy will be
allowed to take the entry level test with a letter from their Academy Commander
stating that they are a current enrolled student in the police academy and show
a graduation date. Any such candidate, upon a passing entry exam grade and upon
passing the physical agility test will be allowed to remain on the eligibility
list with the understanding that they cannot be considered for hire until such
time they graduate and provide proof of their current Ohio Police Officer
Training Certificate. For purposes of the eligibility list they will be
bypassed until such time as the above is completed. Such appointments shall be
in accordance with other requirements as set forth in Ohio R.C. 124.41 and this
chapter except that not more than sixty (60) days prior to receiving an
appointment the applicant shall pass a physical examination established by the
City Administrator and administered by a licensed physician chosen by the City
Administrator.
   (f)    Fire/Rescue Division Applicants.
      (1)    Applicants for examination for original appointment to the Fire
Department as a firefighter shall have obtained the age of eighteen (18).
Applicants shall possess a high school diploma or GED and will present proof of
such prior to testing. Applicants must provide proof of a valid Ohio driver's
license and be considered insurable by the City's insurance carrier. Such
appointments shall be in accordance with other requirements as set forth in
Ohio RC. 124.42 and this chapter. Except that not more than sixty (60) days
prior to receiving an appointment the applicant shall pass a physical
examination established by the City Administrator and administered by a
licensed physician chosen by the Administrator.
      (2)    Effective January 1, 2025, Applicants for examination for Entrance
Level Positions in the Fire Department shall possess the following
certifications.
         A.    Ohio Level I Firefighter; and
         B.    Ohio Emergency Medical Technician.
      (3)    Credit for State Certification.
         A.   Ohio Paramedic certification extra credit. Any candidate who has
received a passing score of seventy percent (70%) or more in the entry level
civil service fire examination shall be granted an additional credit of ten
percent (10%) of such score which shall be added to that score to determine the
final grade if the candidate can show proof of being a current certified State
of Ohio Paramedic.
         B.   Ohio Level II Firefighter certification extra credit. Any
candidate who has received a passing score of seventy percent (70%) or more in
the entry level civil service fire examination shall be granted an additional
credit of ten percent (10%) of such score which shall be added to that score to
determine the final grade if the candidate can show proof of being a current
certified State of Ohio Level II Firefighter.
         C.   Credit for state certification shall apply only to entrance level
applicants, and shall be in addition to any credit given for military service.
The maximum credit any applicant can receive is twenty percent (20%) for any
combination of military and certification credit.
      (4)    Firefighter Fitness for Duty Testing.
         A.   As a part of their application submission, applicants may include
documentation of having completed the National Testing Network's Firefighter
Mile examination. This is to be dated to within one (1) year of the date of
application to be considered valid. Applicants who have valid testing
documentation will be excused from the department's fitness for duty testing
exercise.
         B.   Applicants who do not possess a valid fitness for duty testing
document will be required to complete the department's testing. This process
will be conducted as outlined in the current contract with Tiffin Firefighters'
Local 322.
            (Ord. 2025-2. Passed 1-6-25.)
   149.032 PROMOTION PROCESS.
   (a)    Notice of Examination. Notice of competitive promotional examinations
shall be given by posting of bulletins in conspicuous places in the departments
whose employees may be interested or may be by individual communications to the
employees via their City email account. Such notice shall be given not less
than thirty (30) days prior to the examination unless waived by all persons
eligible to participate. A description of readily available source material
shall be published prior to exam.
   (b)    Nature of Examination. Promotional examinations for all promotions
except mechanic with the Fire/Rescue Division shall consist of a written
examination and assessment center as determined by the City Administrator. The
fire department mechanics exam shall be a written examination only as
determined by the City Administrator. The testing procedures shall be practical
in character and shall relate directly to those matters which shall fairly test
the relative capacity of the person examined to discharge the particular duties
of the position for which the promotion is sought. Only applicants who receive
a final score of seventy (70) or higher may receive consideration for
promotion.
   (c)    Inspection and Protest of Written Examination Papers. Participants in
a written examination may inspect the examination questions together with the
rating key for the questions, the grading thereof, and submit any protests to
the agency administering the examination in accordance with its rules.
      (1)    Prior to scoring, participants in a written examination may
inspect the examination questions together with the rating key for the
questions for a period of not more than five (5) days after the date of
examination, Saturdays, Sundays and holidays excluded. Any protest by a
participant as to the questions asked or the rating key answers shall be filed
with the testing agency who administered the exam. If the agency finds an error
in the rating key or answer, it shall publish a revised rating key within five
(5) days of its finding of such error or errors. The revised rating key or
answer shall then be available to participants for a period of five (5) days,
exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, subsequent to such determination
of
error or errors. The examination papers of each contestant shall be then
scored. The participants shall then have added any applicable credits to the
score and shall be notified through their City email account or verbally as to
their grade. The inspection of written examination papers can be waived, if all
examinees prior to taking the written examination request said waiver in
writing to the Commission.
      (2)    After notice of grade has been received, each participant shall
have the right to inspect their written examination papers together with the
rating key within five (5) days of the date of email or verbal notification of
their grade, Saturdays, Sundays and holidays excluded, and to inform the
participant as to the markings given on each subject or questions. Any protest
as to the grading shall be filed in writing by the participant within the above
five (5) day period, Saturdays, Sundays and holidays excluded. The Commission
shall then give consideration to all protests and make such changes as are
warranted. The Commission shall then establish the eligible list and no grades
given in any examination shall be changed after the posting of any eligible
list.
      (3)    Protest of written examinations conducted by the National Testing
Network must be received within five (5) days of the closure of the application
period, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, subsequent to such
determination of error or errors. Protest must be submitted in writing and
submitted to the City of Tiffin Civil Service Commission.
   (d)    Public Inspection. Papers, except recommendations of former
employers, submitted by competitors in any examination shall be open to public
inspection during office hours upon application to the Commission provided such
application is made during the period in which persons whose names appear on
the eligible list resulting from such examination are eligible for appointment.
   (e)    Examination Postponed. The examination, unless postponed, shall be
held upon a date fixed by the Commission. Examinations may be postponed by
order of the Commission; which order shall designate the reason therefor.
   (f)    Police Officer Promotions.
      (1)    Promotions to positions above the rank of police officer in the
Police Department shall be in accordance with the provisions of Ohio R.C.
Section 124.44, with the exceptions that the seniority requirements for
sergeant shall be five (5) years, all other ranks shall require two (2) years
seniority in the next lower grade.
      (2)    Assessment efficiency and seniority credits shall be as provided
in subsections (h), (i) and (j) hereof respectively.
      (3)    In the event that not more than one candidate is eligible for
examination to a promotional rank because of lack of time in grade or service,
then all persons holding the rank which qualifies them for that examination
shall be deemed eligible regardless of time in grade or service.
      (4)    Results of a promotion process will remain valid for one (1) year
from their compilation and may be used by the City Administrator in determining
additional promotions within the one year period.
      (5)    Candidates for promotion to the rank of sergeant or higher in the
Police Department shall be graduates of an accredited college, university or
institution of higher learning with an associate degree or bachelor degree in
police science/criminal justice, public or business administration, or other
related field as approved by the City Administrator and Civil Service
Commission except that candidates for promotion to the rank of sergeant are
also eligible if they have ten (10) years of law enforcement experience, which
shall include at least five (5) years of employment with the Tiffin Police
Department and may include experience in military law enforcement. The
candidates who were members of the Police Department prior to October 18, 2004,
the effective date of Ordinance No 04-65, which established the education
requirement, shall remain eligible for promotional exams for the rank of
sergeant or higher.
      (6)    The Civil Service Commission shall certify to the City
Administrator the names and addresses of three persons standing highest on the
eligibility list for promotion following the promotional examination,
assessment process efficiency rating, and seniority. The City Administrator at
their discretion shall promote any one of the three persons certified by the
Commission.
   (g)    Fire Fighter Promotions. Promotions to the positions above the rank
of regular fire fighter in the Fire/Rescue Division shall be as follows:
      (1)    Lieutenant Promotions. A candidate for the Lieutenant's exam shall
have completed six (6) years of continuous service as a member of the Tiffin
Fire/Rescue Division prior to the date of the examination, and shall have
completed the following items prior to the announcement date for the position:
         A.    Must be certified as a Fire Safety Inspector or Hazard
Recognition Officer.
         B.    Must have successfully completed Fire Officer I.
         C.    Have obtained NIMS/ICS 100, 200, 700, and 800 training.
      (2)    Captain Promotions. A candidate for the Captain's exam shall have
completed eight (8) years of continuous service as a member of the Tiffin Fire/
Rescue Division, have held the rank of Lieutenant for at least one (1) year
prior to the date of the examination, and shall have completed the following
items prior to the announcement date for the position:
         A.    Must be certified as a Fire Safety Inspector or Hazard
Recognition Officer.
         B.    Must have successfully completed Fire Officer II.
         C.    Must be certified as a Fire and Emergency Services Instructor.
         D.    Have obtained NIMS/ICS 100, 200, 300, 700, and 800 training.
      (3)    Deputy Fire Chief Promotions. An internal candidate for the Deputy
Chiefs exam shall have at least ten (10) years of continuous service as a
member of the Tiffin Fire/Rescue Division, have held the rank of Captain for at
least one (1) year prior to the date of examination, and shall have completed
the following items prior to the announcement date for the position:
         A.    Must be certified as a Fire Safety Inspector.
         B.    Must have successfully completed Fire Officer III.
         C.    Must be certified as a Fire and Emergency Services Instructor.
         D.    Have completed NIMS/ICS 100, 200, 300, 400, 700, and 800
      (4)    Fire Division Mechanic Promotions. A candidate for the Mechanic's
exam shall have successfully completed three (3) years of continuous service as
a member of the Tiffin Fire/Rescue Division and have completed the following
items prior to the announcement date for the position:
         A.    Must be certified as Firefighter II.
         B.    Must be certified as a Paramedic.
      (5)    Candidates for promotion to the rank of Captain or Deputy Chief in
the Tiffin Fire/Rescue Division shall be graduates of an accredited college,
university or institution of higher learning with an associate degree or higher
in fire science, fire administration, public or business administration, or
other related field as approved by the City Administrator and Civil Service
Commission.
         A.    This section shall only apply to those individuals who became
members of the Fire and Rescue Division after January 1, 2015.
      (6)    Those individuals wishing to take a promotional exam must provide
documentation to the Civil Service Commission showing they meet the minimum
requirements for the position.
         A.    Documentation shall consist of the following:
            1.    A written letter of intent declaring an interest in competing
for the promotion.
            2.    Copies of all required certificates of training and education
for the promoted level being sought as found in Section
149.032(g).
               a.    In order to be accepted all certificates of training and
education must be completed prior to the date the vacancy examination is
announced.
               b.    Documentation may be submitted via USPS, emailed or hand
delivered to the City Administrator.
      (7)    In the event that no more than one candidate is eligible and
willing to take the examination for Captain, Lieutenant, or Mechanic because of
time in grade or service, then all persons meeting the training and education
requirements which qualifies them for that examination shall be deemed eligible
regardless of the time in grade or service.
         A.    In the event that no more than one candidate is eligible to
examination for Captain, Lieutenant, or Mechanic the qualified candidate shall
be awarded the position.
      (8)    Assessment, efficiency, and seniority credit shall be as provided
in subsections (h), (i) and (i) hereof, respectively.
      (9)    Results of a promotion process will remain valid for one year from
their certification by the Civil Service Commission and may be used by the City
Administrator in determining additional promotions within the one year period.
   (h)    Assessment Process and Credit.
      (1)    The assessment credit for promotion purposes shall be based on an
assessment process conducted by an outside testing company chosen by the
department head, City Administrator and the Civil Service Commission; provided,
however, that in the event that only one applicant receives a final score of
seventy (70) or higher on the written examination then such applicant shall be
awarded the position without conducting an assessment process.
      (2)    The purpose of the assessment process shall be to evaluate the
applicant's practical ability to perform the necessary duties and functions of
the position for which the promotion is sought.
      (3)    To qualify to take the assessment center an applicant must score a
minimum of seventy percent (70%) on the written exam.
      (4)    The method of scoring assessment centers shall be based on maximum
final score of 100 points. The scoring process used by the assessment panel
shall be approved by the Civil Service Commission prior to the date of the
exam.
   (i)    Efficiency Rating and Credit.
      (1)    The efficiency rating for promotion purposes shall be based on the
average of the two most recent efficiency ratings prepared on an applicant with
either the police department or fire department under this section.
      (2)    Department efficiency rating system shall be based on 100 points
as the highest attainable score.
      (3)    The efficiency rating system shall be determined by the City
Administrator, shall be related to job performance, and shall be submitted to
Council for approval by resolution.
   (j)    Seniority Credit.
      (1)    Applicants in the promotion process shall receive credit for
seniority, which shall be determined as follows: One point shall be added to
the total grade for each year of service within the department following the
second year and through the sixteenth year. A maximum of fourteen (14) points
can be awarded. Partial years of service shall be calculated as a percentage of
the year. The date the test is administered shall determine years of service.
   (k)    Credit Weight for Police Department Examinations. All credits
applicable to the promotion process are weighted as follows:
 
Written Test      45%
Assessment credit 45%
Seniority Credit  5%
Efficiency Credit 5%
   For examinations involving written tests only credit shall be weighed as
follows:
 
Written Test   90%
Efficiency Credit 5%
Seniority credit  5%
   (1)    Credit Weight for Fire Department Examinations. All credits
applicable to the promotion process are weighted as follows:
 
Written Test      35%
Assessment Credit 55%
Seniority Credit  5%
Efficiency Credit 5%
   For examinations involving written tests only credit shall be weighed as
follows:
 
Written Test   90%
Seniority Credit  5%
Efficiency Credit 5%
   (m)    Eligibility for Repeating Examinations. No person who has taken a
competitive assembled examination for a promoted position shall be permitted to
be re-examined for the same classification within one hundred eighty (180)
calendar days from the date of the examination unless a substantially different
form of the examination is used.
   (n)    Promotions. Vacancies in positions in the classified service shall be
filled insofar as practicable by promotions. Promotional appointments shall be
made in accordance with the provisions of Ohio R.C. Section 124.31 with the
exception of those of policemen in the Police Department and of firefighters in
the Fire Department. Promotion of policemen shall be made in accordance with
the provisions of Ohio R.C. 124.44 and this chapter. Promotion of fire fighters
shall be made in accordance with the provisions of Ohio R.C. 124.45 except as
provided for in this chapter. (Ord. 2025-2. Passed 1-6-25.)
   149.033 APPOINTMENT OF CHIEF OF POLICE.
   (a)    The Police Chief shall be appointed by the Mayor pursuant to the
provisions of Charter Section
7.04(E)(1) and subject to such rules and procedures that Council may
promulgate.
   (b)    Applicants for the position of Police Chief shall meet the following
minimum requirements:
      (1)    Shall be a citizen of the United States and have not less than ten
(10) years of actual police experience in a full-time law enforcement position
with progressively higher levels of management experience consisting of at
least five (5) years as a Chief of Police or five years in an administrative or
upper management level police position comparable to the position of captain or
lieutenant in the City Police Department.
      (2)    At the time of application for the position of Police Chief the
applicant must be employed as a Police Chief or as a police officer in an
administrative position or upper management level law enforcement position, or
employed as such within the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding the
date of application.
      (3)    Effective January 1, 1998, a candidate must be a graduate of an
accredited college or university with a bachelor degree in criminal justice,
public or business administration or other related field. A candidate must
present certification of formal training that demonstrates significant
experience in crime prevention, supervision, decision-making, management and
leadership.
      (4)    Graduation from the Federal Bureau of Investigation National
Academy, Southern Police Institute Command Officers Course, Northwestern
University Command Officers Course or the Police Executive Leadership College
with emphasis on the executive development and management sciences shall be
recommended and preferred, but not required.
      (5)    Must pass a psychological examination, polygraph examination,
medical examination and the then current physical fitness for duty standards of
the Police Department.
      (6)    Shall have a valid Ohio driver's license or be capable of
obtaining one prior to appointment.
      (7)    Shall have no prior felony convictions or pending criminal suits.
      (8)   Must be certified as a peace officer by the State of Ohio Peace
Officers Training Council at the time of appointment or within the legal time
limitations then set by the State.
   (c)    Applicants for the position of Police Chief shall submit an
application accompanied by all appropriate documentation necessary to prove the
applicant's ability to meet the minimum requirements of subsection (b) hereof.
All applications shall be accepted by the Civil Service Commission and
processed through the Assessment Center Process Board. The Commission and Board
may use any mutually agreeable method to limit the number of final applicants
to a maximum of ten (10) persons. The final applicants determined to best meet
the City's needs and qualifications will be tested by the Assessment Center
Process by the Assessment Center Board. The applicants will be rated by the
Assessment Center Board in a numerical order based upon the results of the
Assessment Center Process. The three (3) highest ranking candidates' names
shall be submitted to the Mayor for appointment pursuant to subsection (a)
hereof. All other names on the list and the order of their ranking shall remain
the confidential information of the Civil Service Commission.
   (d)   If one (1) or more of the three (3) names submitted to the Mayor is
found not qualified for the position based upon the requirements of subsection
(b) hereof, an equal number of names shall be submitted to the Mayor by the
Civil Service Commission from the eligibility list in the order of their
ranking on the list.
   (e)    The eligibility list shall remain in effect for one (1) year from the
date the list is certified as being in effect by the Civil Service Commission.
   (f)    The Mayor shall choose one (1) person from the list of three (3)
names submitted to him or as amended by the Civil Service Commission.
   (g)    Any person on the eligibility list that is not presently a member of
the City Police Department shall not be subject to the requirements of Section
141.02(b) as it pertains to an original appointment. The person hired from the
list shall be subject to all other ordinances or laws applicable to this
position or to employment by the City in general.
(Ord. 2024-78. Passed 10-7-24.)
   149.034 APPOINTMENT OF FIRE CHIEF.
   (a)    The Fire Chief shall be appointed by the Mayor pursuant to the
provisions of Charter Section
7.04(E)(1) and subject to such rules and procedures that Council may
promulgate.
   (b)    Applicants for the position of Fire Chief shall meet the following
minimum requirements:
      (1)    Shall be a citizen of the United States
      (2)    Have not less than ten years of actual experience within a fire
department that provides both fire and EMS services with progressively higher
levels of management experience consisting of at least two (2) years as a Chief
Officer or two (2) years in an administrative or upper management level fire
position comparable to the position of captain or lieutenant in a full-time
fire department.
      (3)    Completion of NIMS/ ICS including: NIMS/ICS 100,200,300,400, 700,
800
      (4)    Must be certified as a Level II Firefighter, Paramedic, and Fire
Safety Inspector through the State of Ohio at the time of appointment or within
one (1) year.
      (5)    A candidate must be a graduate of an accredited college or
university with a bachelor degree or higher in public or business
administration, fire science or other related field.
      (6)    In addition to the requirements above, preference will be given to
those individuals who possess training/ experience in the following area:
         A.   Completion of NFPA 1021, Fire Officer I, II, III and IV programs
         B.   Certified Fire and Emergency Services Instructor,
         C.   Public fire education training,
         D.   Sprinkler systems,
         E.   Previous experience working in a college or university community
         F.   Executive Leadership,
         G.   Fire cause and origin,
         H.   Insurance Service Office rating system, and
         I.   Fire service supervision including health, safety and survival;
      (7)    Capable of passing a psychological examination, polygraph
examination, medical examination, and the current physical fitness for duty
standards of the City Fire Department.
      (8)    Shall have a valid Ohio Drivers License.
      (9)    Shall have no prior felony convictions or pending criminal suits.
   
   (c)    Applicants for the position of Fire Chief shall submit an application
accompanied by all appropriate documentation necessary to prove the applicant's
ability to meet the requirements of subsection (b) hereof. All applications
will be accepted by the Civil Service Commission and processed through the
Assessment Center Process Board. The Commission and Board may use any mutually
agreeable method to limit the number of final applicants to a maximum of ten
(10) persons. The final applicants determined to best meet the City's needs and
qualifications will be tested by the Assessment Center Process by the
Assessment Center Board. The applicants will be rated by the Assessment Center
Board in a numerical order based upon the results of the Assessment Center
Process. The three (3) highest ranking candidates' names shall be submitted to
the Mayor for appointment pursuant to subsection (a) hereof. All other names on
the list and the order of their ranking shall remain the confidential
information of the Civil Service Commission.
   (d)    If one (1) or more of the three names submitted to the Mayor is found
not qualified for the position based upon the requirements of subsection (b)
hereof, an equal number of names shall be submitted to the Mayor by the Civil
Service Commission from the eligibility list in the order of their ranking on
the list.
   (e)    The eligibility list shall remain in effect for one (1) year from the
date the list is certified as being in effect by the Civil Service Commission.
   (f)    The Mayor shall choose one person from the list of three names
submitted to him or as amended by the Civil Service Commission.
   (g)    The person hired from the list shall be subject to all other
ordinances or laws applicable to this position or to employment by the City in
general.
(Ord. 2024-78. Passed 10-7-24.)
   149.035 APPOINTMENT OF DEPUTY FIRE CHIEF.
   (a)    Section
149.035 shall only apply if there is no qualified applicant from within the
Tiffin Fire/Rescue Division meeting the requirements described in Section
149.032(g)(3) for promotion to the Deputy Chief position.
      (1)    Notice of the application period shall be given through multiple
media sources including, but not limited to, the local newspapers, social
media, email, radio, and any other medium useful for delivery of information to
the public. Notices shall appear not more than sixty (60) days or less than
thirty (30) days prior to the closure of the application period.
   (b)    Applicants for the position of Deputy Fire Chief shall meet the
following minimum requirements:
      (1)    Be a citizen of the United States.
      (2)    Have not less than ten (10) years of continual experience within a
full-time fire department that provides both fire and EMS services with
progressively higher levels of management experience consisting of at least two
(2) years in an administrative or upper management level fire position
comparable to the position of captain or lieutenant.
      (3)    Completion of NIMS/ICS 100, 200, 700, 800.
      (4)    Completion of a Fire Officer III program.
      (5)    Be certified as a Firefighter Level II, Paramedic, and Fire Safety
Inspector through the State of Ohio.
      (6)    Be certified as a Fire and Emergency Services Instructor through
the State of Ohio.
      (7)    The candidate must be a graduate of an accredited college or
university with an associate's degree or higher in public or business
administration, fire science, or other related field.
      (8)    Hold a valid Ohio Driver's License and maintain insurability
through the city's insurance carrier.
      (9)    Have no prior felony convictions or pending criminal suits.
   (c)    Applicants for the position of Deputy Fire Chief shall submit an
application accompanied by all appropriate documentation necessary to prove the
applicant's ability to meet the requirements of subsection (b) hereof. All
application packets will be accepted and certified by the Civil Service
Commission and then the Review Committee. This committee shall consist of the
City Administrator, the Human Resources Director, and the Fire Chief. The
Review Committee may use any mutually agreeable method to limit the number of
final applicants to a maximum of ten persons. The final applicants determined
to best meet the City's needs shall complete a written examination as
determined by the City Administrator. Those applicants scoring seventy percent
(70%) or better will then be tested by an Assessment Process as described in
Section
149.032 (e). The applicants will be rated by the Assessment Center Board in a
numerical order based upon the results of the Assessment Center Process. If
three (3) or fewer applicants are eligible for the assessment center, the
ranking will be based on the written test scores only. There will be no
efficiency rating or seniority credit awarded regardless of the number of
applicants. The names of the three (3) highest ranking candidates shall be
certified by the Civil Service Commission then submitted to the Review
Committee for interviews. The City Administrator at their discretion shall
appoint any one of the top three (3) persons certified by the Commission. All
other names on the list and the order of their ranking shall remain the
confidential information of the Civil Service Commission.
      (1)    Credit Weight for the Deputy Chiefs Examination
         A.    Credits for appointment under Section
149.035 will be as follows:
            Written Test          40%
            Assessment Credit       60%
   (d)    The eligibility list shall remain in effect for one year from the
date the list is certified as being in effect by the Civil Service Commission.
(Ord. 2024-78. Passed 10-7-24.)
   149.04 ELIGIBLE LISTS.
   (a)    Eligible lists established under this chapter for promotional
certification shall continue for a period of one year for police and fire
fighters from the date of certification. Eligible lists established under this
chapter for entrance level certification shall continue for a period of two (2)
years for police and fire fighters from the date of certification.
   (b)    Where an eligible list exists and a vacancy occurs which may be
filled from such eligible list for either the police or fire service, the
vacancy shall be filled within a period of not more than thirty (30) days from
the date of such vacancy.
   (c)    No Current List.
      (1)    The Commission, in the absence of a current eligible list for
promotional positions, shall not administer an examination for any position
unless the City Administrator notifies the Commission that a vacancy will exist
which would require certification.
      (2)    The City Administrator shall notify the Commission within seven
(7) days after he/she becomes aware that a vacancy will exist in a position
which would require certification for appointment or promotion.
      (3)    In the absence of a current eligible list and after being notified
that a vacancy will exist, the Commission shall administer the proper
examination no less than sixty (60) nor more than ninety (90) days after
receiving notification of a vacancy. Within one hundred and twenty (120) days
of receiving the vacancy notification the Commission shall have completed
testing, created an eligibility list, and certified the proper number of names
from the list to the proper appointing authority.
   (d)    Entrance Level Eligibility Lists.
      (1)    The Fire/Rescue Division and the Police Department utilizing the
National Testing Network (NTN) can request an eligibility list from NTN at any
time as they maintain a master list at all times from participants. When
requested and received from the NTN the list shall rank the candidates in order
with the highest scoring candidate being ranked number one.
         A.    Candidate lists obtained from NTN will be certified by the Civil
Service Commission as the eligibility list to hire from for both the Fire/
Rescue Division and Police Department. The eligibility list shall be certified
until such time when the list needs to be updated in order to maintain a
minimum number of applicants.
   (e)   Names Not To be Certified For Appointment. The name of any person
appearing on an eligible list who:
      (1)    Fails to report or arrange within six (6) days after receipt of
notification, Saturdays, Sundays and holidays excluded, for an interview with
an appointing authority;
      (2)    Fails to respond to a notice from the Civil Service Commission;
      (3)    Declines an appointment without reasons satisfactory to the Civil
Service Commission; or
      (4)    Cannot be located by the postal authorities; shall not thereafter
be certified to any appointing authority as eligible for appointment, unless a
thoroughly satisfactory explanation of the circumstances is made to the
Commission. The eligible person shall be notified to this effect unless their
whereabouts are unknown.
   (f)    Causes for Disqualification from New Hire Lists.
      (1)    Although rejection may be based upon causes other than those
enumerated, the following are declared to be cause for rejection of the
application or disqualification of applicant, if the City Administrator shall
find that the applicant:
         A    Is found to lack any of the minimum qualifications as stated in
the entrance level eligibility list establishment posting.
         B.    Is unable to perform the essential functions of the position for
which the candidate sought appointment with or without reasonable
accommodation.
         C.    Tests positive for the use of alcohol, illegal drugs, or the
illegal use of prescribed drugs.
         D.    Has been previously dismissed from any public service for
inefficiency, delinquency or misconduct, or has quit City service under
charges.
         E.    Has been guilty of any crime(s) that would preclude the
applicant from employment based on job relatedness.
         F.    Has intentionally made a false statement of any material fact,
or has practiced or attempted to practice any deception or fraud in an
application or examination.
         G.    Is not able to achieve insurability with the City's insurance
carrier.
         H.    Has not completed eligibility requirements as to length of
service by the final date for submitting applications as set forth in the
examination announcement.
      (2)    Any person who, by order of the City Administrator, is denied
permission to compete in any examination, or whose examination is disqualified
may, within five (5) days of notice of rejection or disqualification, appeal in
writing to the Civil Service Commission for a review of such ruling. The
Commission shall afford such appellant an opportunity to be heard.
      (3)    Failure to submit a complete application, as described in the
eligibility list or promotional posting, on or before the last date for
receiving applications may be deemed sufficient cause for rejection.
   (g)    Change of Address. Each person on an eligible list shall file with
the Commission written notice of any change of address, and failure to do so
may be considered sufficient reason for not certifying their name to appointing
authorities for future appointments.
   (h)    Tie Grade. In the event two or more applicants receive the same
grade, priority shall be first given and granted to any provisional appointee,
then applicants who are veterans shall receive priority in rank on the eligible
list over non-veterans on the list with a grade equal to the veteran. All other
ties in rank shall be decided at the discretion of the appointing authority.
(Ord. 2024-78. Passed 10-7-24.)
   149.05 APPOINTMENTS AND PROMOTIONS.
   (a)    Police Officer Appointments. There shall be two (2) methods for
original appointment of police officers: civil service entrance level process
with a certified eligible list and lateral hire. The City Administrator may
decide to consider candidates from either list to fill a vacancy. Subsection
(a) hereof is specifically intended to supersede the Ohio Revised Code for
original appointments to police officer positions in the Police Department.
      (1)    Civil Service entrance level process. Applicants are required to
complete a written examination and the Civil Service Commission shall certify
the names on an entrance level eligibility list in accordance with this
Chapter.
         A.    When the City Administrator requests the Civil Service
Commission to certify a list of persons eligible and willing to accept an
appointment to one or more existing vacancies in the position of patrol
officer, the Commission shall certify such names, beginning with the person
listed highest in priority on the eligibility list, after verifying that the
individuals are currently eligible and willing to be considered for
appointment. If an individual is eligible but not willing to be considered for
an appointment at the time of this certification list is prepared, the
Commission shall make a formal determination, based on existing circumstances,
as to whether that individual's name shall be removed from the eligibility list
and thereby from consideration for any future certification lists. The
Commission shall certify to the City Administrator the minimum number of names
which will permit the City Administrator to fully comply with the procedures in
subsection (a)(1)B. below. One certification list may contain enough names to
allow the City Administrator to fill more than one vacancy from the same
certification list.
         B.    When filling a vacancy in the position of police officer, the
City Administrator shall, utilizing such means as the City Administrator
determines to be appropriate, select the person to be appointed from among the
top six (6) names certified by the Civil Service Commission. If more than one
position is to be filled from the same certification list, the City
Administrator shall, for each position, start at the top of the list and
consider the top six (6) eligible names remaining on the list.
         C.    The Civil Service Commission shall place the names of the
examinees on the eligible list in accordance with their grades; the one
receiving the highest grade shall be placed first on the list. In the event two
(2) or more examinees receive the same grade, seniority in the police
department shall determine the order of their names. The person having the
highest position on the list shall be appointed in case of vacancy.
         D.    A person who has been certified from the same eligible list
three (3) times to the appointing authority and has been passed over for a
person with a lower score on the list shall be omitted from future
certification.
      (2)    Lateral hire process. Applicants in the lateral hire process will
submit an employment application to the Director of Human Resources.
         A.    In addition, applicants for lateral hire must conform to all of
the minimum requirements of Chapter
149, Civil Service Regulations, and shall meet the following prerequisites:
            i.    An applicant must currently or have previously been employed
as a peace officer;
            ii.    An applicant must be Ohio Peace Officer Training Academy
(OPOTA) certified;
            iii.    For applicants previously employed as a peace officer,
there shall be no more than a one-year break in service from previous
employment as a peace officer.
         B.    The Police Chief, in conjunction with the Director of Human
Resources and the City Administrator, will review resumes and applications to
determine which applicants meet the lateral hire criteria in this subsection
149.05(a)(2). Lateral hire applicants may be required to submit to the
following, including but not limited to, a thorough background investigation,
polygraph examination, psychological and medical evaluation, oral interview by
an assessment board from the Police Department utilizing an interview rating
sheet prepared by the Department, and drug screening. Utilizing the interview
rating sheet, the assessment board will compile an overall score for each
applicant interviewed and submit such findings to the Commission ranking each
applicant from highest scored to lowest scored. The Commission will then
certify the lateral hire list. This list shall remain in effect for one (I)
year from the date of certification.
         C.    Positions filled through the lateral hire process are exempt
from competitive examination.
         D.    Applicants appointed as a police officer through the lateral
hire process must successfully complete a twelve (12)-month probationary period
or as otherwise provided by the collective bargaining agreement.
         E.    Patrol Officer Grade Classification for lateral hired police
officers will be credited based on prior service in the position of police
officer. Lateral hired police officers shall receive one year credit for prior
service for each one year of prior service for purposes of pay and benefits. In
no event shall a lateral hired police officer receive more than five (5) years
credit with the City of Tiffin.
         F.    Employees selected through the lateral hire process shall obtain
and retain all other rights attributed to the classified service, following
successful completion of the probationary period.
      (3)    Upon the City Administrator's designation of either a certified
eligible list or a lateral hire list, the City must use that list until it is
exhausted.
      (4)    The Civil Service Commission is authorized to promulgate rules and
procedures for the administration of the test and selection methodology of both
methods of original appointment not inconsistent with this subsection (a).
   (b)    Firefighter Appointments. The City Administrator may, depending upon
the City's operational needs, request an eligibility list from either the
lateral hire or entry level list for the original appointment of a firefighter.
However, upon designating a list, the City is limited to using that list until
the designated list is exhausted. The Civil Service Commission is authorized to
promulgate rules and procedures for the administration of the test and
selection methodology of both methods of original appointment not inconsistent
with this subsection (b).
      (1)    Civil Service entrance level process. Applicants are required to
complete a written examination and the Civil Service Commission shall certify
the names on an entrance level eligibility list in accordance with this
Chapter.
         A.    When the City Administrator requests the Civil Service
Commission to certify a list of persons eligible and willing to accept an
appointment to one or more existing vacancies in the position of firefighter,
the Commission shall certify such names, beginning with the person listed
highest in priority on the eligibility list, after verifying that the
individuals are currently eligible and willing to be considered for
appointment. If an individual is eligible but not able or willing to be
considered for an appointment at the time this certification list is prepared,
the Commission shall make a formal determination, based on existing
circumstances, as to whether that individual's name should be removed from the
eligibility list and thereby from consideration for any future certification
lists. The Commission shall certify to the City Administrator the minimum
number of names which will permit the City Administrator to fully comply with
the procedures in subsection (c), below. One certification list may contain
enough names to allow the City Administrator to fill more than one vacancy from
the same certification list.
         B.    When filling a vacancy in the position of firefighter, the City
Administrator shall, utilizing such means as the City Administrator determines
to be appropriate, select the person to be appointed from among the top six (6)
names certified by the Civil Service Commission. If more than one position is
to be filled from the same certification list, the City Administrator shall for
each position, start at the top of the list and consider the top six (6)
eligible names remaining on the list.
         C.    The Civil Service Commission shall place the names of the
examinees on the eligible list in accordance with their grades; the one
receiving the highest grade shall be placed first on the list. In event two (2)
or more examinees receive the same grade, the dates of original certification
for Level II Firefighter in Ohio with older dates considered higher shall
determine the order of their names. The person having the highest position on
the list shall be appointed in case of a vacancy.
         D.    A person who has been certified from the same eligible list
three (3) times to the appointing authority and has been passed over for a
person with a lower score on the list shall be omitted from future
certification.
      (2)    Lateral Hire Process.
         A.    Applicants for lateral hire positions must show they are a
current, or recent, full-time firefighter contributing into the Ohio Police and
Fire Pension System. Individuals must be in good standing in the fire
department in which the applicant serves. In the event of an employment
separation, not more than six (6) months shall have elapsed between the
separation and the employment application being received by the City of Tiffin.
Applicants must have a minimum of one (1) year full time firefighter experience
in the last eighteen (18) months in the State of Ohio and have held both their
professional firefighter and Emergency Medical Technician or Paramedic
certifications during this time.
         B.    To be considered for employment, a completed City of Tiffin
Application for Employment shall be submitted and postmarked by the application
closing date. The applicant must also provide current Level II Firefighter and
Emergency Medical Technician or Paramedic certifications from the State of
Ohio.
            i.    As lateral hires, applicants are exempted from the National
Testing Network exam and physical agility testing.
            ii.    Application forms for inclusion in the lateral hire pool
shall be separate from those for the written entry level examination and shall
be compiled by the Fire/Rescue Division and approved by the Civil Service
Commission.
            iii.    All lateral hire applicants shall be interviewed by an
assessment board from the Fire/Rescue Division, utilizing an interview rating
sheet prepared by the Division.
            iv.    Utilizing the interview rating sheet, the assessment board
will compile an overall score for each applicant interviewed and submit such
findings to the Commission ranking each applicant from highest scored to lowest
scored. There will be no credit added for state certification or military
service. The Commission will then certify the lateral hire list. This list
shall remain in effect for one (1) year from the date of certification.
         C.    Any individual on the lateral hire list, if chosen for
appointment to the Division, shall enter as a Firefighter/EMT or Firefighter/
Paramedic only and shall be subject to a one (1) year probationary period.
         D.    Any individual hired who is not certified as a Paramedic is
subject to the timeline established in Section
143.03, Certification Requirements.
         E.    Upon a conditional job offer being made, the applicant must
submit to and pass a background check and new employee physical.
         F.    In the event an applicant for lateral hire is unsuccessful, the
applicant may elect to apply under the civil service entrance level process. In
that event, all rules and regulations relative to application, examinations,
and credits will apply. At no time shall an individual be considered on a
certified lateral hire list and a certified entrance level list.
            (Ord. 2024-78. Passed 10-7-24.)
   149.06 PROBATIONARY PERIOD AND DEMOTIONS.
   (a)    Probationary Period: Probationary Removal or Reduction.
      (1)    All original and promotional appointments including provisional
appointments shall be for a probationary period. No appointment or promotion is
final until the appointee has satisfactorily served their probationary period.
      (2)    Probationary employees who are assigned to a temporary modified-
duty assignment shall have their probation extended by a period of time equal
to their assignment to temporary modified duty.
      (3)    The probationary periods of various classes of positions in the
several services of the City, are as follows:
            POLICE DEPARTMENT
 
Chief          3 months
Lieutenant     6 months
Sergeant       9 months
Police Officer 1 year
            FIRE DEPARTMENT
 
Chief        3 months
Deputy Chief 6 months
Captain      6 months
Lieutenant   9 months
Mechanic     9 months
Fire Fighter 1 year*
* A minimum of one (1) year but may extend to thirty-six (36) months to allow
for achievement of Firefighter II and/or Paramedic certifications.
         All other Personnel shall be for one year; this includes persons hired
from outside the City for any position within the classified service.
      (4)    Service as a provisional employee in the same or similar class
shall be included in the probationary period. If the service of the
probationary employee is unsatisfactory, they may be removed or reduced during
their probationary period after completion of sixty days. Unless the
probationary appointee has been removed or reduced earlier, the appointing
authority, at any time during the ten (10) day period before the end of the
probationary period, shall inform the Commission, in writing, of the decision
either to make the appointment of the probationary appointee final or to remove
such appointee. If the appointing authority's decision is to remove the
appointee, their communication to the Commission shall state the reason for
such decision.
   
   (b)    Demotions. Employees demoted due to disciplinary actions, failing
their probationary period, or requesting voluntary demotion shall be reduced to
the employee's former class and rate, insofar as possible while still achieving
the department composition. In the event no vacancy at the former class exists
the employee may be reduced to the class of entry level, however, their rate
would adjust that of their former rate.
(Ord. 2024-78. Passed 10-7-24.)
   149.07 GENERAL RULES.
   (a)    Supersession of State Code. This chapter shall supersede any
conflicting sections of the Ohio Revised Code, by authority of the Home Rule
Charter of the City. Whenever this chapter or the Charter of the City is silent
concerning matters of Civil Service, then provisions of the Ohio Revised Code
shall prevail.
   (b)    Civil Service Commission Rules. The Commission may adopt and publish
other rules of procedure not conflicting with this chapter in accordance with
the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 2024-78. Passed 10-7-24.)
   149.08 POLITICAL ACTIVITY ALLOWED.
   (a)    Officers and employees in the classified service of the City shall,
notwithstanding the provisions of Ohio R.C. 124.57, be allowed to become
candidates for any public office, other than a municipal office of the City of
Tiffin. As candidates they shall be permitted to do any acts in furtherance of
their candidacy not otherwise prohibited by law, so long as such acts are not
performed during their hours of employment, or otherwise assigned active duty
hours. Furthermore, no employee shall use their position of employment to
further their campaign except as a statement of their qualifications for the
public office.
   (b)   A violation of this section shall be considered a cause for discharge,
suspension, demotion or other discipline pursuant to Section
7.04(F)(5) of the Charter of the City of Tiffin.
   (c)   Any elected public officer of the City, meaning the Mayor, Director of
Finance, Director of Law, members of Council and President of Council, may
serve in an additional public position if such position is:
      (1)    Appointive and not elective,
      (2)    It has been determined by opinion of the Director of Law, County
Prosecutor or State Attorney General, or the designee of such offices, that the
appointive position is not in conflict with the above listed positions in the
municipal government of the City.
   (d)    (1)    The appointive positions may not be within the City municipal
government unless so provided by ordinance.
      (2)    They may be at the county, state or federal level.
      (3)    Request for legal opinion shall be made by the prospective
appointee, or the appointing authority, to the Director of Law, who may seek
assistance of the County Prosecutor or Attorney General.
      (4)    Approval by Council is not required, and continuance in an
appointive position does not depend on continuance in office with the City.
         (Ord. 2024-78. Passed 10-7-24.)
   149.09 REVIEW OF EVALUATIONS.
   As soon as practicable after the completion of a written evaluation of any
employee of the City, the head or designee of such department shall review the
evaluation in person with the employee, advising them of their performance in
each of the rating categories and explaining the reasons for such scores. In
addition, areas where the employee is strong, as well as areas where
improvement is suggested, shall be explained to the employee.
(Ord. 2024-78. Passed 10-7-24.)
   149.10 EFFECTIVE DATES OF EDUCATIONAL REQUIREMENTS.
   The educational requirements for promotions of firefighters to Lieutenant,
Captain, Deputy Chief, and Mechanic identified in Section
149.032(g)(1), (2), (3), (4) Fire Fighter Promotions, shall become the sole
education requirements for all promotional exams given after January 1, 2025.
(Ord. 2024-78. Passed 10-7-24.)

CHAPTER 153
Enterprise Zone
153.01   Enterprise Zone Committee.
153.02   Purpose of enterprise zone.
153.03   Guidelines for use of enterprise zone.
153.04   Application process.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Enterprise Zones - see Ohio R.C. 5709.61 et seq.
 
153.01 ENTERPRISE ZONE COMMITTEE.
   There is hereby created an Enterprise Zone Committee. The Committee's voting
membership shall be composed of the three members of the Law and Community
Planning Committee of Council. The Committee's non-voting ex-officio members
shall be the Mayor and Director of Law of the City, the President of the Seneca
Industrial and Economic Development Corporation and the Superintendent of
Tiffin Public Schools or his designate. This Committee shall be chaired by the
chairman of the Law and Community Planning Committee of Council.
(Ord. 86-11. Passed 3-3-86.)
153.02 PURPOSE OF ENTERPRISE ZONE.
   The enterprise zone in the City is intended to be used as a tool for the
economic revitalization of the community by providing local and state tax
incentives to businesses which create or retain jobs in the City by investing
in plants, equipment and inventory.
(Ord. 86-11. Passed 3-3-86.)
153.03 GUIDELINES FOR USE OF ENTERPRISE ZONE.
   (a)   The enterprise zone program may be used by industrial, commercial, and
service firms which construct, occupy, renovate or expand within the enterprise
zone. The program will not normally be available to retail sales
establishments, and shall not be applied to retail inventories.
   (b)   This program should not be used to provide to any firm a competitive
economic advantage over any other firm already existing in the City.
   (c)   Proposed uses of the program must have a significant beneficial impact
on the City.
   (d)   If this program is used for job creation, a preference in hiring for
the new positions should be given to current residents of the City unless
needed job skills are not available locally.
   (e)   Consideration shall be given to the relationship between the economic
benefits to be gained by the City from the project and the amount of tax
dollars being abated.
(Ord. 86-11. Passed 3-3-86.)
   (f)   Any agreement entered into under this process is based upon the
acceptance of the facts that depreciation is considered customary in valuation
of personal property and that normal cyclical or technological factors as well
as temporary inventory adjustment, will cause variances in tax valuation and
tax liability. Therefore, under the provisions of this program, a basis for
termination may exist if the recipient business enterprise's annual personal
property tax valuation is reduced more than fifty percent (50%) based on the
annual average of the prior three years. Termination under those circumstances
will be based on mutual agreement, but if such accord is not possible, then a
decision as to modification of the agreement or termination may be made by an
arbitrator named by a judicial officer of this County from nominees selected by
the City and the business entity, such arbitration expenses to be borne equally
by the City and the business.
(Ord. 88-41. Passed 8-1-88.)
153.04 APPLICATION PROCESS.
   (a)   Application information and forms may be obtained from the Office of
the Mayor and shall be submitted to that office. The completed application must
be accompanied by a non-refundable two hundred dollars ($200.00) application
processing fee.
   (b)   Data required to be submitted on and with the application, or required
by the Committee, shall be verified and analyzed by persons or firms to be
designated by the Enterprise Zone Committee.
   (c)   The Committee, or persons designated by it, shall conduct a "cost -
benefit analysis" of the proposed project.
   (d)   When terms of an agreement have been agreed upon by the applicant and
the Committee, the terms shall be forwarded to the Director of Law for
preparation of a contract and an implementing ordinance, which shall be offered
to Council for introduction as soon as practicable.
   (e)   Any completed agreement shall provide for payment by the applicant of
an implementation fee equal to two and one-half percent (2 1/2%) of the
estimated tax savings to the applicant over the life of the agreement based on
data provided in the application and verified by the Committee. Such fees shall
be deposited in the City's Revolving Loan Fund.
   (f)   The agreement shall take effect upon approval of Council by ordinance
and upon execution of the written agreement by all necessary parties. The
agreement shall then be processed by the City pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter
5709.
(Ord. 86-11. Passed 3-3-86.)
CHAPTER 155
Park and Recreation Board
155.01   Management of personnel.
155.02   Contracting Powers.
155.03   Employees.
155.04   Purchases.

155.01 MANAGEMENT OF PERSONNEL.
   The Park and Recreation Board shall have the authority to implement
classifications for personnel needed for its programs, recommend rates of
compensation for such positions, determine entrance level qualifications,
performance standards, provisions for hiring and provisions for terminations
for good cause, and shall establish written regulations governing such
procedures.
(Ord. 89-2. Passed 2-6-89.)
155.02 CONTRACTING POWERS.
   (a)   The Park and Recreation Board shall have the authority to contract for
services to be provided by any individual or organization in the opinion of the
Board qualified to advise, consult, manage, plan or otherwise assist the Board
as to recreation programs, swimming pool operation and management. Such
management contracts may be separate, and shall be governed by applicable
statutes as to advertising and public bidding, and shall not be for a term of
more than one calendar year without prior approval of Council by ordinance.
   (b)   All contracts shall be prepared by or approved by the Director of Law.
(Ord. 89-2. Passed 2-6-89.)
155.03 EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   All paid personnel engaged in services for the Park and Recreation
Board shall be employees of the City of Tiffin, and shall be either full-time
or part-time employees by designation of the Board or a designated member
thereof, and subject to statutory or ordinance rules governing such employment.
   (b)   The Park and Recreation Board shall not be an employer for purposes of
collective bargaining as contemplated by Chapter 4117, Public Employees'
Collective Bargaining Act.
(Ord. 89-2. Passed 2-6-89.)
155.04 PURCHASES.
   All purchases for material needed to carry into effect proper usage of the
parks and to implement recreation programs shall be by requisition to the City
Administrator, and subject to all required criteria for advertising, bidding
and payment terms, including the Finance Director's certificate of availability
of funds.
(Ord. 89-2. Passed 2-6-89.)
CHAPTER 157
Arts Commission
157.01    Establishment.
157.02    Membership; terms.
157.03    Purpose.
157.04    Powers and duties.
157.05    Reports.
157.06    Compensation.
157.01  ESTABLISHMENT.
   The City of Tiffin Municipal Arts Commission is hereby established.
(Ord. 21-78. Passed 9-20-21.)
157.02 MEMBERSHIP; TERMS.
   The Municipal Arts Commission shall consist of five to seven members, all of
whom shall be residents of the City or owners of one or more businesses located
in the City. All of the members shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to the
approval of the Council by a vote of a majority of its members. One member
shall be a liaison to City Council charged with coordinating Commission
activities with the City. The Mayor, City Administrator, or their designee
shall serve as an ex-officio member with a vote. The originally appointed
members shall serve staggered terms of one, two and three years designated by
the Mayor. Successors to those members originally appointed and any newly
appointed members to increase the number of serving members shall thereafter be
appointed for terms of three years each. The Municipal Arts Commission shall
adopt such other organizational procedures and policies not inconsistent with
this chapter subject to the approval of the Mayor.
(Ord. 21-78. Passed 9-20-21.)
157.03 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of the City of Tiffin Municipal Arts Commission is to promote
public art to enhance, enliven and enrich the lives of its citizens and guests
while reflecting its community values. (Ord. 21-78. Passed 9-20-21.)
    
157.04 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The powers and duties of the Municipal Arts Commission shall be as follows:
   (a)   Participate in identifying and developing possible public art sites
for City Council approval;
   (b)   Draft and distribute calls for artists, stating project goals and site
plans;
   (c)   Convene art selection panels as needed;
   (d)   Participate in City Council meetings where public art is discussed;
   (e)   Prepare and monitor all tracking documents, including artist records,
art inventories, and contracts;
   (f)   Coordinate all physical and logistical components of artwork
installations;
   (g)   Coordinate preparation of all necessary signage, including
identification labels and/or plaques;
   (h)   Coordinate publicity and media attention for artwork installations;
   (i)   Serve as a conduit between artists, project and building managers,
city staff and others as necessary to ensure a trouble-free flow;
   (j)   Serve as a resource, guide, and counsel to the City Council and city
staff regarding all issues related to the Municipal Art Program;
   (k)   Hold regular meetings to respond to any conceptual proposals and any
other business deemed appropriate to the Commission's purpose;
   (l)   Review more specific renderings and details for approved projects for
the purpose of making recommendations on final approval of a project
specifically addressing whether a proposed project meets the Commission's
purpose;
   (m)   Conduct an annual planning process that results in priorities and
specific activities centering on its purpose;
   (n)   Upon request of City Council, serve as a jury regarding the artistic
quality and merit of a proposed project, determining whether the project meets
the Commission's purpose;
   (o)   Recommend actions that could be taken to accomplish the goals of the
city;
   (p)   Carry out such other duties as may be assigned by the Mayor or City
Council.
      (Ord. 21-78. Passed 9-20-21.)
157.05 REPORTS.
   The Municipal Arts Commission shall submit an annual report to City Council
concerning the activities and work of the Commission and from time to time
shall submit such reports and recommendations as may be necessary to fulfill
its purpose.
(Ord. 21-78. Passed 9-20-21.)
157.06 COMPENSATION.
   The members of the Municipal Arts Commission shall receive no compensation
for their service as members thereof.
(Ord. 21-78. Passed 9-20-21.)
CHAPTER 159
Weller Memorial Commission
159.01   Established.
159.02   Membership.
159.03   Duties.
159.04   Appointment and terms of members.
159.05   Officers.
159.06   Council to provide office.

159.09   Clerk.
159.10   Annual report to Council.
159.11   Commission to act independently.
159.12   Expenses of members.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to establish - see CHTR. Sec.
7.06
Organization; vacancies - see CHTR. Sec.
7.07
Special funds authorized - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 5705
 
159.01 ESTABLISHED.
   The Julia M. Weller Memorial Commission is hereby established.
(1951 Code Sec. 7.24)
159.02 MEMBERSHIP.
   The Weller Memorial Commission shall consist of five electors of the City.
Not more than three members of the Commission shall, at any time, be from any
one political party.
(1951 Code Sec. 7.25)
159.03 DUTIES.
   The Weller Memorial Commission shall handle the bonds, securities and funds
coming to the City from the estate of Julia M. Weller, deceased, late of the
City, the Commission and its successors shall invest and re-invest in
perpetuity the funds bequeathed to the City by Julia M. Weller, in bonds or
other obligations of the United States or of the State, and bonds or other
interest bearing obligations of any county, city or school district within the
State, provided such county, city or school district has not defaulted in the
payment of the interest on any of its bonds or other interest bearing
obligations, for a period of more than one hundred and twenty days during the
ten years immediately preceding the investment by the Commission, and provided
further that such county, city or school district, is not, at the time of such
investment, in default in the payment of principal or interest on any of its
bonds or other interest bearing obligations. The income derived from such bonds
is to be used to aid and help the crippled children and the blind of the City
and especially for the furnishing of surgical and medical assistance for the
amelioration of the condition of such crippled children and blind residents of
the City.
(1951 Code Sec. 7.26)
159.04 APPOINTMENT AND TERMS OF MEMBERS.
   In December of each year the Mayor shall appoint one member of the
Commission who shall serve for a term of five years, commencing on the first
day of January following, or until his successor is appointed and qualified,
such appointment to be approved by Council.
(1951 Code Sec. 7.27)
159.05 OFFICERS.
   The officers of the Weller Memorial Commission shall consist of a president,
who shall be the member having the shortest term to serve, a vice-president,
secretary and treasurer. The vice-president, secretary and treasurer shall be
elected by the Commission at its first regular meeting in January of each year,
and shall serve for a term of one year.
(1951 Code Sec. 7.28)
159.06 COUNCIL TO PROVIDE OFFICE.
   Council shall provide a suitable office in the Municipal Building for the
use of the Weller Memorial Commission in the transaction of its business.
(1951 Code Sec. 7.29)
159.07 ADOPTION OF RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Weller Memorial Commission shall adopt such rules and regulations, as
shall be necessary for the conduct of its business, and for carrying into
effect the wishes of the late Julia M. Weller.
(1951 Code Sec. 7.30)
159.08 COPY OF WILL TO BE KEPT ON FILE.
   The Weller Memorial Commission shall obtain and keep on file a certified
copy of the last will and testament of Julia M. Weller, deceased.
(1951 Code Sec. 7.31)
159.09 CLERK.
   The Weller Memorial Commission may, in its discretion, employ a clerk to
keep its records, and to perform such other duties as the Commission may
direct, at a salary to be fixed by the Commission, within its discretion.
(Ord. 70-90. Passed 1-4-71.)
159.10 ANNUAL REPORT TO COUNCIL.
   The Weller Memorial Commission shall, on the first day of January of each
year, submit a written report to Council giving a full statement of its
proceedings for the preceding year.
(1951 Code Sec. 7.33)
159.11 COMMISSION TO ACT INDEPENDENTLY.
   The Julia M. Weller Memorial Commission shall act independently and shall
not be connected in any way, whatsoever, with any other commission or
organization engaged in similar work in the City.
(1951 Code Sec. 7.35)
159.12 EXPENSES OF MEMBERS.
   The members of the Julia M. Weller Memorial Commission shall receive no
salary for their services rendered, but shall receive their actual expenses
incurred in the discharge of their official duties, such expenses to be paid
out of the funds of the Commission.
(1951 Code Sec. 7.36)
CHAPTER 161
Conner Memorial Commission
161.01   Established
161.02   Membership.

CROSS REFERENCES
Power to establish - see CHTR. Sec.
 7.06
